text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with boston baked beans or at least
how I make them I hope it's relatively
authentic but I never do so here we go I
have one pound of navy beans you got to
soak those overnight in lots of water
alright going to drain those throw that
in a Dutch oven with six cups of water a
pinch of baking soda which apparently
does something to tenderize the bean or
so I heard or it might do nothing I
don't know I put it anyway and a bay
leaf
bring that to a boil and cook for 10
minutes alright so after those boil for
10 minutes you're going to drain them
drain that through a colander into a big
bowl save the liquid transfer the beans
into the pot we're going to add our
bacon and by the way I like bacon
because it's you know smoky and it's
bacon but traditionally they use salt
pork in this so if you want to use salt
pork go for it we're going to toss in
our minced onions you of course can
leave the bay leaf there from the
boiling we're going to add molasses God
that stuff's slow some black pepper some
salt some dry mustard and some brown
sugar
alright stir that until combined and
then we're going to take some of that
reserved hot bean boiling liquid and
we're going to add that just to cover
just barely to cover alright so don't
worry about measuring because what
you're going to do is you're going to
bake these until tender adding water
when needed so as long as you have
enough just barely to cover to start
here you're in good shape
alright cover that tightly with your lid
that's why these heavy Dutch oven type
things work the best if you have one of
those bean pots they actually sell
Boston baked bean pots of course you're
going to use that we're going to put
that in a 300 degree oven for one hour
then we're going to check it so what are
we looking for here the liquid level so
the liquids going to be absorbed by the
beans and what you want to do is just
add a little more to kind of bring it
back up to the just coverage stage at
this point you don't really want to stir
it just check in a liquid level that's
going to go in for another hour and then
you got to play it by ear okay they may
be getting tender at this point they may
not if not let them cook a little longer
but what you want is them to just about
be tender they've just about absorbed
the liquid you're going to remove the
cover and cook them at 350 to give the
top a nice crust the bake is going to
caramelize a little alright the liquids
gonna thicken up and get kind of Sur P
and that's really what you're looking
for so you got to play this Bayer I will
give you the times approximately but you
really got to play by ear
okay the beans should be tender and the
liquid should be evaporated reduced down
to the kind of a surfeit consistency and
that's it Boston baked beans not the
most visually exciting thing I've ever
made but just really really delicious
and you know great side dish with
anything so I hope you give those a try
Boston baked beans or at least my
version go to the site all the
ingredients are there and as always
enjoy
